title: Lockable Ball & Socket Pivot Joint For Helping Hands

description.text:
One thing I really want to be able to do with the maker bot is make more things to help me make more things. This is an experimental design for a lockable pivot joint intended to be used (with about 5 brothers) in making a set of helping hands to hold circuit boards etc. This should print without any problems on a makerbot (although it's small at the bottom so may be a little unstable - need to watch that :) The sections join onto each other and the nut can be used to tighten the joint or lock it in a fixed position. This could also be used to create pose-able armatures. The full design for the helping hands is not ready (I've not finished modeling the clamp grips (variations of the same mechanical principle). This is my first attempt at a screw/bolt thread, if anyone tries to print this out please let me know how it goes, I try very hard to respond to feedback in my designs and I'm happy to take suggestions. UPDATE:
An updated version of this part can be found in my helping hands design: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2972

This design has not been tested
1 STL 2 parts - Print at least 2 in order to see how they connect to each other.
SKP included for those who are interested.

comments.text:
Additionally, the thread is reversed! I had same issue with a downloaded thread used for my model!
With this thread, the nut would need to be screwed counterclockwise.
Just resize it by "-1" scale in Sketchup.
comments.author: jumpjack

comments.text: How is it supposed to lock?? Screw is not conical!
comments.author: jumpjack

comments.text:
What is the size of this object?
If that
Ã‚Â´s an M8 or M10-screw, then the details may be much too fine to print.
A extruded thread of plastic at 0.25mm layer-height is 0.25*1.8=0.45mm thick
and thatÃ‚Â´s the maximum resolution I ever achieved.
comments.author: MarcusWolschon

comments.text: The question of resolution is what I wanted to know about, The core around which I make the thread is 10mm in diameter, To give you an idea about the thread size, the nut is 5mm deep and has only 2.5 rotations.
comments.author: MarcusWolschon

comments.text: I like the idea - a completely printable PCB clamp.  Were you thinking that the base would have multiple sockets for multiple flexi-arms?  One thing keep an eye on is the size of the base - a couple of other PCB clamps posted here were unstable on account of having too small a footprint.  One way around that is the base on this clamp:

author: whowhatwhere

description.text: I was asked to design an iPhone Dock that would allow the phone to be held and charged in either the upright or side positions. This thing should allow you to place your iphone on its side, and still be plugged in. I do not have my own i-device, so I grabbed measurements for the connector base from here: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:9459

I have included the Sketchup .skp file for anyone to edit. Depending on your printer the orientation will need to be changed, and or support enabled or added to help with the overhangs.
  • Print
  • Watch iphone
  • Profit??

The finger cap below is a device that attempts to protect patients who have diabetic neuropathy from injuries resulting from physical trauma. For example, if a person with this form of neuropathy attempts to cook, they may cut their thumbs while slicing vegetables. Similarly, person could be protected from injuries such as paper cuts. This finger cap is designed to protect the thumb from damage. The bottom would be custom sized to fit each individual by scaling the x and y axis before printing the object.

• Download the stl file.

  • Print a test "Cap"

  • Scale the file on the x and y axis to get a perfect fit.

title: Replicator 1 HBP height adjustment retaining jig (Total revamp)

description.text: This little device slips over two of the HBP height adjusting knobs to prevent them from working lose during the vibration incured during printing. I printed it weeks ago and put it to the test doing large heavy prints that used to make me adjust each new print. Atfer installing these I've yet to make an adjustment.

The jig clips on front to back, or back to front. One for each side. I printed mine at .20mm, 1 shells, 15% infill, no raft, 110-240C- enclosed   
I did another run to fix an issue and now have a new file. Did again and now have a really tight fitting jig. Included are two spreads to preload the jig so instalation is quick. Just open the clamps and hold open with the raised part on the rectangle pieces. When in place (narrow side up) just pop the off the pieces holding the jaws open. It's now on tight.  
Anidotal note: My first set printed fine and worked well for me. A freind went with a Rep1 and printed a set, then another, on the third he came over, tossed then in my lap stating 'your better than this, fix it'.  He was correct, they were junk because my stl was junk. So I redesigned it right this time. Now it's 'wow went on easy, hope they can come off agian'. They do and the HBP does not drift up over time do to fibration. Sorry (thx fastrack) I didn't pursue the issue when first mentions in the replies.

comments.text: Be VERY careful when installing these, so the knobs don't move. They fit very snug. The spreaders aren't in the file. They're not really necessary, though. Maybe that's why.
comments.author: j0hnnyxm4s

comments.text: Heh, I use a dial indicator to ensure the level of my bed, and had it installed when I put on my bars. Whenever I attach the bars, the dial indicator moves up by about 0.005" (~.127mm)! Is that normal?
comments.author: jasonwebb

comments.text: Yes it can be if the jig is touching the wood. If not touching just compensate by adjusting the nuts a little before installing.
comments.author: jasonwebb

comments.text: I've lately been experiencing needing to adjust the HBP more frequently (probably mostly due to recents prints being long-running prints) -- I saw this when it first came out, before I had even thought about buying a Replicator. Â I'm glad I remembered this thing, and was able to find it on Thingiverse! Â Thanks for putting this together!
comments.author: toybuilder

comments.text: Â Thanks, it was a real necessity for me, and for may others too. I haven't needed to adjust the bed for months. I'm set kind of close,Â  .008 inch I think on a .0.2mm layer height and I usually have to hit the print with 'freeze off' to get it off without tearing the tape.
comments.author: toybuilder

comments.text: A lot of people were complaining about missing infill. Â I tried Print-o-matic 1,2,3 shells with anywhere between 10-50% infill. Â The left side hooks were always empty and part of the right as well. Â I changed it to 0 shells and 25% infill. Â The end hooks now get filled in perfectly.

comments.text: "when you are level, the back screws are loose" because when you turn one screw, it affects the level of the other 2 screws. You're probably turning the screws separately instead of all together. Even without your device, you should be able to make at least 3 to 4 large prints (tornado cups) before you need to re-level unless you are levelling by turning the screws separately. Do the following:
comments.author: latigerlilly

comments.text: I made a set and level is holding for at least 10 prints. It is too early to say if they make a real difference, but I expect it will help. Time will tell!
comments.author: Busybotz

comments.text: Great, I'm interested in hearing if it works for others as well. When my HBP is level my back two springs are quite loose. I made the jig a little tight length wise to keep a good grip. I've gone over a month with mine and I recently finished the last of some large and heavy(5oz.) prints that was killing my leveling early on before the jig. Now the level is still spot on. It's been a good fix for me.
comments.author: Busybotz

comments.text: Success! I have seen a clear improvement since installing these clamps. At least 20 prints, and the bed did not require any adjustment at all, even for plated sets that nearly filled the platform. That is a big deal, because I was always fighting with the bed adjustments.
comments.author: 66tbirdJZ

comments.text: Thank you for the heads up on my .02 error. It should of been .20mm
comments.author: 66tbirdJZ

comments.text: I don't think that the makerbot replicator is capable of printing in 0.02 mm height layers. I read somewhere that the limit is 0.04 mm (sorry, I forgot where. I think it was makerbot T.V. or the Google Makerbot Forum). I think the OP meant 0.2 mm. That's how I printed it and I also got one side hollow with the other side solid. I think you'll have to use a higher fill percentage than 15% if you want both sides to be solid.
comments.author: latigerlilly

comments.text: It was 0.2 thanks. I don't know why the forks are different. Mine wer both solid. :-[  I see no problem with a higher infill.
comments.author: latigerlilly

comments.text: I am prining them right now, I put me layers to .25, since I don't want to try .02 just yet.

comments.text: Nice solution! I have yet to experience that degree of movement but It cant hurt to install them before it happens! Great preventative thinking!

description.text:
My pond pump runs on a swich, which is convenient for maintainance, but makes it a pain when roomates stumble in looking for the lights.
So here's my solution, a switch cover that requires no panel modification.

After having my first print pop up and fail (See Picture), I added another base to help with base adhesion (Xsupport).
Both files are included in case you want to make modifications, just list me under your derivative!
You'll likely want to generate some support material as well.
Let me know if you have requests or questions!

description.text: A friend asked me to make him a replacement FOB for is Isuzu Trooper. Both of his originals had broken in the same place. I made some modifications to the original to make it a little more stout around the area where it broke off.

a swiveling banana stand. this was inspired by thing 280982. i wanted something a little more heavy duty looking to match my kitchen. this was printed with black madesolid pet+ then lightly faux finished to give a cast iron look.
the base prints great as is, no support. the banana part should be printed upright just like the model is set. print with 80-100% support.

comments.text: There's always money in the bannana stand.
comments.author: holycrapitsmyles

description.text: This is used to level the HBP on a Makerbot Replicator. Holds a Power fist 2.25" Deflection Gauge (.375" center mount) & 4 Rare earth magnets (8mmx3mm). Both are available from Princess Auto in Canada Gauge #2970986 - $18.99 & Magnets #8183915 - $2.49. When fully inserted there's only about 2.5mm pressure on the gauge spring, so the HBP does not deflect.

Printed at .27, 15% infill, 1 shell. Default Speed. Insert the Deflection Gauge into the holder until it's flush with the bottom. Home your Axis, position the nozzle just in front of the right-back screw. Use your piece of paper or feeler gauge. Place the gauge on the carraige rods, it can easily slide around on the rods! Adjust until you get zero everywhere :) I based this off of Heathzaps tinkercad object, as his applied too much downward force on the HBP and my gauge or magnets did not fit. I also extended the area downwards around the rods so it does not move when moving it around. Original Tinkercad object:
https://tinkercad.com/things/c7fIJL0vQIn-powerfist-dial-deflection-gauge-holder

comments.text: FYI, the Harbor Freight's 'Pittsburgh 1 In. Travel Machinist's Dial Indicator, item#623' (http://www.harborfreight.com/1-inch-travel-machinists-dial-indicator-623.html) will fit this holder and the holder will sit on the FlashForge Creator Pro's rods/rails perfectly. I can't attest for accuracy yet as I haven't bought the magnets yet. The gauge pushed the holder and itself up slightly without the magnets.
comments.author: olav216

comments.text: Yeah with the magnets it will work perfectly :)   I also found you want to limit the amount of compression on the dial indicator spring, ie I usually do a few rotations of the needle, and have the needle close to 12 o'clock.  Reset it to zero and go.
comments.author: olav216

comments.text: Thanks for your advice! Will try it.

title: Galaxy Note keyboard holder and stand

description.text:
A keyboard holder for the Galaxy Note and Hama/Brando bluetooth keyboards. The holder can also be used as a stand in both horizontal and vertical orientation, when attaching the two T shaped parts to it. Easy to assemble and disassemble.
Fits into any pocket. It's a way of turning your Galaxy Note into a tiny netbook and saving screen real estate at the same time. This is especially useful when combined with a classical linux userland, e.g. the Ubuntu app. Although just using it for IRC or Soup.io is probably fine too ;-)

Printing of this object takes about 8g ABS and 30 minutes on a RepMan 3.0 at 245 degrees celsius.
The BFB code has been generated using Axon2 with 0.5mm layer thickness and 100% filling. Chyllds derafter has been used to remove the raft pattern.

author: abhipat

title: Interstellar Space Jarhead - Biker Enthusiast
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Rescaled, fixed mesh errors, adjusted legs to sit properly on the bike. Snip the hand at the wrist, rotate, re-glue. Updated to include the sidecart "heavy assault" version. When printing sidecart, split it slicer to take the two attachment points underneath it out. Then drop and print. Will print much easier that way. Trying to stay in line with Games Workshop IP Policy. If any GW employee or representative wishes me to remove or alter any designs, let me know and I will comply with expediency. Below I’ve outlined how I tried to comply with their policies.
.
Overall - None of these are exact replicas. I tried to add abit of my own take on things or modification to the design. Ei kitbash it abit. Additionally, all models should just be used for painting practice. Practice messing up a paint job on a print, not your actual GW model.
.
Copyrights - I tried to make sure a “significant part” was not the same. Style, yes. Copied, no.
.
Trademark - I’ve removed all specific Trademarks. Ex: Aquila
Non-commercial - I’m making no money from this
.
Professional Distribution - I’m not a professional artist, using any of these as a portfolio advertisement. Just a hobbiest tinkering
.
Damage our brand - Not doing that. GW IP is a pretty cool universe. Hence the reason I wanted to make models that “live” in it.
.
Make it clear you’re doing it unofficial - I’m doing this UNOFFICIALLY.
.
Use trademarks appropriately - I tried to remove all trademarks
.
Derivative Works - I believe most of these models would fall under derivative works, two are three models might not, but I think most do.
.
Non-commercial recasting and 3D printing - I have not scanned any of GW’s IP.

comments.text: I love it ! Looks really easy to print
comments.author: SebTheis

comments.text: Started printing, the bikes look great!  Can you post individual files for the bikes and the 'jarhead' bits?  I needed a raft for the bits, but the bikes would be better w/o the raft.  Also it'd be nice if I could just reprint one if it got messed up.
comments.author: kresty

comments.text: VERY nice. What resolution are you using? Your centurions turned out better than mine :)
comments.author: Garin

comments.text:
The biggest thing I've found for getting good prints is just having all the stepper motors dialed in. I think that makes more of a difference than step size. I only use the 50mm + sized calibration angles. I've found anything smaller than that, doesnt work too well. If you've got your x,y, and Z reallie dialed in - in general the print come out looking much better.
I typically print at 0.25 Z, with a 0.4 Nozzle. I need to fix some Z banding issues though. They are very visible on the dozer blade and the centurian's shoulder. I'm getting those because my Z threaded rod is "soft" mounted to my Z stepper, instead of hard mounted like it should be.
I've also found for alot of these models, I try to avoid printing parts together. For example I print the head separate from the torso or the guns separate from the arms. That seems to let them pick up more detail when sliced. After slicing I will sometimes ever so slightly increase a model size, like 1%, to see if that picks me up another layer. Sometimes just one more layers makes the difference between something looking rounded and something looking boxy.
Ask and you shall receive. Uploading now
comments.author: outofstep

comments.text: Prints awesome...  Any thoughts about making a 3 wheeled version for extra firepower? :)
comments.author: creiht

author: outofstep

title: Jeep Commander Power Seat Cam Shaft

description.text: This is a replacement part for a Jeep commander Power Seat. The power seat will loose motion on the front Z axis. The original part is made cheaply and hollow where the cam pushes the most, Bad design on Jeep. This piece is not available separately, but as a whole assembly from jeep for the hefty price of $650.00. This was the deciding factor to build a 3D printer. Take that, Jeep.
I measured the original part. Then printed it.

comments.text: I have no need for this item but love the fact you have designed a part to save others a ton of money, and the fact you probably spent less on your printer setup than the part cost.  Congrats!
comments.author: Bmays

author: beebenutz

description.text: I made this Whorephanage from the show and movie Black Dynamite on Adult Swim, contest. Again since this is a design contest, I did not put the letters in a seperate file.
If you are going to print, remove letters and put them into another 3D rendering program so you can print them out separably and ad-hear them to the whorephanage.

author: kyle01r6

description.text:
The last time I played the tabletop game The Resistance, I realized that it was sometimes difficult to see information that was needed to make decisions in the game, specifically the mission and leader cards. It seemed that if these cards were standing up in front of the player with the card, it would be easier to quickly follow what was happening during the course of the game.   
An easy solution was to create a small holder that the cards can be inserted into so that they stand up. Many other games include these card stands as game components, but for those that do not, now there is an easy way to create custom card holders.  
The customizer can be used to generate a holder that fits your specific game piece, simply measure the thickness of the game piece in millimeters and enter that value into the customizer.
Customized version of http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:40703 Created with Customizer! http://www.thingiverse.com/apps/customizer/run?thing_id=40703

Using the following options: case_thickness = 1.8
build_plate_selector = 0
pattern_rotation = 0
pattern_radius = 20
iphone_version = 1
pattern_overlap = 93
pattern_thickness = 3
pattern_shape = 6

I designed a compact mechanical endstop holder for a second Orca i am building.
Reason for nearly closed case is that it will hold the endstop better than only two short fans (when properly printed) and for a optical nicer look.
Corners are all rounded for better and faster printing Should also fit any other printer with 8mm rod
Vitamins : M3x20mm screw + nut

comments.text:
I've been looking all over for this!!! I bought my electronics from MakerFarm and they had originally these compact holders for my Prusa Air2. I snapped one of them (they were getting old) and the other "straight" holders would extend out too far (they would trigger on the Y-bed edge instead of the linear bearing pillow blocks) which would chop 15-25 mm off of my Y-Axis!
I'm so relieved I found this... I temporarily used one of the "extended" holders to print these and now I'm at full printing capacity. Whew!

description.text:
I found a nice simple cold-end design (thing #275593) and made some changes based on my needs.  
This version uses a different bearing and drive pulley - the same parts that come with QU-BD's one-up / two-up printers (this is for an upgrade to one of those printers, re-using as many parts as possible).  
Also added a thumb lever to help with changing filament, switched the quick-connect coupling for a M4 nut coupling, added a taper to the inside of the output channel to help with threading filament through, and various other minor alterations.  
Updated: v2 of design posted

comments.text: Do you have measurements or recommendations for a spring replacement? My second hand Oneup is missing that spring! (HW13) I tightened the bolt with an allen key while holding the nut with my fingers until it "felt right" and surprisingly it prints pretty well. I'd like to build this extruder (and am waiting on the last piece to print) but need to know about the spring.

comments.text: For future reference I used a #2 sprint from Ace Hardware and a 45mm screw.

comments.author: drsmooth

comments.text: One thing to keep in mind is that the stock extruder system has the hot-end and cold-end components all together mounted right on the X carriage. This is convenient because it is not very complex, but it also means that the weight of the motor causes stress on the X rail - the main source of "sag" in the system.
comments.author: drsmooth

comments.text: Thank you for that perfect explanation.  I was trying to understand what a Bowden system was but only found info on VW clutches.
comments.author: MacAttak

comments.text: This is only a cold-end portion of an extrusion system. Yes, you can use it with a new printer however you will also need a hot-end carriage as well as a length of PTFE tubing to connect the cold-end to the hot-end. Here are three examples of hot-end carriages that you could use:
comments.author: drsmooth

comments.text: Hi MacAttak. Thanks for sharing your remix. I like your idea of using an M4 hexnut to fasten the bowden tube. Do you mind if I would merge this option in my design? I'm already looking forward hearing from you how your extruder performs.

comments.author: schlotzz

comments.text: Wow, thanks for your fast answer!
comments.author: MacAttak

comments.text: I believe the stepper is also a Wantai but not certain of the exact model. The disk measures as 22.25mm on my calipers. After double-checking the actual printed object I am suspecting that my steps/mm is out of adjustment for X and Y - about 0.6mm out of calibration in both over the ~45mm size of the extruder base. I recently updated firmware and might have clobbered those config settings. So your sizing might be OK for that. (the bolt holes would still benefit from polyholes though - my miscalibration is only a small factor for the drills)
comments.author: schlotzz

comments.text: Recalibrated my X and Y steps/mm and changed the bolt holes to use polyholes method, and it comes out great now.
comments.author: MacAttak

comments.text: I added the tensioner slot a few days ago on my idler, too. It works like a charm and helped a lot.
comments.author: MacAttak

comments.text: If I remember correctly, that should make it roughly twice it's current size, so it would have about 1/4" thick walls. I think that should be plenty strong enough as long as you printed it with an adequate amount of fill, maybe 50% or so. If you do end up using this please send some pictures of the final result!
